awd_titl_txt: RII Track-1: CPU2AL: Connecting the Plasma Universe to Plasma Technology in Alabama
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description
Plasmas - a state of matter consisting of a collection of electrically neutral atoms, molecules, as well as partially or fully ionized particles - make up more than 90% of the observable universe and underpin several high-tech manufacturing industries. Familiar forms of plasma include the sun, stars, lightning, neon signs, television screen displays, welder?s torches, and rocket exhaust. This project will improve understanding of plasma processes and interactions. This knowledge will be used to develop new technologies for aerospace, manufacturing, medicine, agriculture, and food safety. The research includes prediction and preparation of novel materials that have unique electronic, optical, mechanical, and biological properties. Applications include prosthetics and plant seed and food disinfection. The project will share resources and leverage partnerships among Alabama institutions of higher learning and industries as well as establish national and international collaborations to strengthen the research capacity and to build and train an inclusive workforce in plasma science and technology.

Technical Description
This project will combine experimental, theoretical, and computational approaches to understand, predict, and control low temperature plasma (LTP) processes and properties. The goal is to improve understanding of plasma kinetics, collective processes such as turbulence and self-organization, and plasma interactions with solid, liquid, biomaterials, as well as plant seeds and food. Kinetic and fluid descriptions of the LTP constituents in space, laboratory, and industrial plasma and diagnostics to measure plasma properties in LTP far from equilibrium will be developed. For collective processes, waves, instabilities, nonlinear processes, turbulence, and self-organization in LTP will be modeled and efficient numerical algorithms for collective effects that influence microwave, THz, and laser-produced plasma will be developed. The research on interactions will focus on large-area deposition of novel super-hard structures and understanding plasma interactions with biomaterials. CPU2AL will facilitate plasma science and technology related programs that reach all levels of education. These include: faculty, postdoc, and student exchanges among all participating institutions, industry internships, summer undergraduate research programs with international opportunities, cross-institutional courses, workshops and training sessions for industry workers, and open houses with student poster and K-12 teacher training sessions.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA IN HUNTSVILLE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation’s EPSCoR Research Infrastructure Improvement (RII) Track-1 project, Connecting the Plasma Universe to Plasma Technology in Alabama (CPU2AL) (OIA-1655280) project was a statewide collaborative effort that sought to understand, predict, and control the transfer of power from electromagnetic fields to electrons, ions, atoms, molecules, and surfaces, and chemical reactions in in low-temperature plasma (LTP) and on surfaces. The project, led by the University of Alabama in Huntsville (UAH), is a consortium of nine Alabama (AL) universities including Auburn University (AU), the University of Alabama in Birmingham (UAB), Tuskegee University (TU), the University of Alabama (UA), Alabama A&M University (AAMU), the University of South Alabama (USA), Alabama State University (ASU), and Oakwood University and an industrial partner, Computational Fluid Dynamics Research Corporation (CFDRC).

Intellectual Merit

Applications developed by CPU2AL include 1) LTP techniques that modify biomaterial surfaces to be either hydrophobic or hydrophilic, allowing these tailored surfaces to control cellular interactions ; 2) the interaction of an iodine plasma with spacecraft materials to accelerate reaction rates for the attachment of refractory metals; 3) the fabrication of a large area 30 cm x 30 cm microwave plasma chemical vapor deposition system for scale-up synthesis of novel materials; 4)  in situ optical emission spectroscopy diagnostics to implement real-time control of the material deposition process; 5) developing atmospheric pressure cold plasma jets and disseminating them among CPU2AL institutions for applications in agriculture, disinfection, and plant physiology, and 6) utilizing LTP to extract useful polymers from waste products. Application of LTP science to agriculture includes 1) the hastening of seed germination and sprouting in turmeric rhizomes, seedling growth, improved plant growth, and high rhizome yields.  LTP is a potential green technology for improving crop productivity. 2) reducing the growth of seed-and food-borne pathogens in bell pepper, fresh poultry meat and ready-to-eat cold-smoked salmon, suggesting that LTP might provide a chemical-free agent for seed sterilization and fresh food safety.

Highlights of fundamental LTP research include 1) new plasma sources for the formation and characterization of dusty plasmas and the production of plasmas at atmospheric pressure; 2) experiments characterizing the thermodynamic properties of dusty plasmas using the PK-4 instrument on the International Space Station; 3) developing new experimental and computational capabilities in atomic emission spectroscopy in plasmas, including the purchase of a high performance, “portable” spectrometer that enabled collaborative measurements between partner institutions; 4)  experimental and computational modeling of pattern formation in magnetized plasmas that enabled scaled ionospheric plasma studies; 5) multi-scale solvers for electron kinetics based on adaptive meshes in phase space for applications to the solar wind, Langmuir probes, and dust charging; 6) an Adaptive Mesh and Algorithm Refinement (AMAR) Framework using grid-based kinetic and fluid solvers with automatic domain decomposition with applications in the solar wind, plasma interactions with liquid interfaces, laser-induced plasmas, and implicit simulations of gas discharges; 7) simulations of plasma stratification in noble gases and clarification of the non-linear and nonlocal effects on ionization waves in DC and AC discharges, and 8) design, delivery, launch and deployment of the JAGSAT 1 CubeSat.

Broader Impacts

Long-term improvements and increased diversity in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) pipeline and workforce in Alabama through the hiring of 6 new faculty members, 5 of which are women. UAH hired three new Assistant Professors in the Department of Space Science, Auburn University one new faculty member in LTP theory, and UAB two new physics faculty members, both of whom are now tenured and promoted to Associate Professor. Two of the UAB and one of the UAH faculty were awarded prestigious NSF CAREER awards.

Immersive training in LTP-related inter- and intra-disciplinary science and research was provided to numerous undergraduate and graduate students. 64 undergraduate students from Alabama and the Southeastern EPSCoR region participated in CPU2AL summer research internships at the nine partner universities. Alabama companies and CPU2AL provided 20 Alabama undergraduate students with LTP corporate internships.

Multiple STEM outreach events to K-12 students and Science and Technology Open House events for middle school teachers and students were provided throughout Alabama. Scholarships to underrepresented and economically disadvantaged youth and rising eighth-grade girls were provided for the summer Science Matters program and the Tech Trek Camp respectively, both intensive hands-on STEM programs.

For the first time, the CPU2AL partner universities collaborated across multiple fundamental and applied plasma physics fields. Translational research was facilitated by shared equipment and expertise between AU, UAH, UA, and CFDRC plasma science and engineering groups and material science groups at Tuskegee and UAB and agricultural science, plant and food microbiology, and food science groups at AAMU, ASU, Oakwood, and Auburn. The collaboration combined theory, modeling, and experimental validation of LTP, with application to industrial applications, realizing the extraordinary potential of LTP science for transformative technological solutions that address grand challenge problems, advanced manufacturing and materials, biomedicine, agriculture, and food safety.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/15/2023
Modified by: Gary P Zank
